awd_titl_txt: Conference: Motivic and non-commutative aspects of enumerative geometry, Homotopy theory, K-theory, and trace methods
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the travel and local expenses of early-career U.S.-based mathematicians to attend the conferences "Motivic and non-commutative aspects of enumerative geometry" and "Homotopy theory, K-theory, and trace methods" in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, held from July 3-7th, 2023. The conferences focuses on exciting, interconnected areas of mathematics which broadly study foundational questions in algebraic K-theory. The events aim to connect U.S.-based mathematicians with European researchers and provide opportunities to build new collaborations. In addition to the interaction with more established researchers in the field, sessions of short presentations are designed to allow graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early career faculty to share their own work.

Algebraic K-theory records important and subtle invariants of a ring or scheme. Unfortunately, computing these K-groups outside of a handful of examples is notoriously difficult. Two dominant approaches have arisen to tackle this problem: motivic homotopy, which builds in algebraic geometry many classical constructions from stable homotopy theory, and trace methods, which approximate the algebraic K-groups by constructions in classical and equivariant stable homotopy. These conferences will bring together experts representing all of these areas and several related fields in mathematics, building on exciting recent developments and providing a forum to expose early-career mathematicians in algebraic geometry and homotopy theory to these areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

This award supported participant travel to the paired events: "Motivic and non-commutative aspects of enumerative geometry" and "Homotopy theory, K-theory, and trace methods" which took place at Radboud Univeristy Nijmegen, the Netherlands, from July 3-7th, 2023. More information about the conferences can be found at the websites:

https://www.math.ru.nl/mnc-conference/

https://www.math.ru.nl/hkt-conference/

The events had an audience of about 90 mathematicians, and they featured in total 21 invited talks and 11 short, submitted talks by early career researchers. The primary focus was to create an opportunity for mathematicians working with motivic homotopy theory, enumerative geometry, and in trace methods in algebraic K-theory to discuss cutting-edge mathematics. A particular goal was to build opportunities for early-career mathematicians to discuss mathematics with experts in the field and to share their research.

Intellectual Merit:

Algebraic geometry seeks to understand algebraic objects like rings and fields using geometric tools. Since the early 2000s, researchers have imported the tools of abstract stable homotopy theory to this context, building an area now described as "motivic homotopy". This has provided new tools to study many classically inaccessible problems, with a particular emphasis on computations with algebraic K-theory.

The algebraic K-groups are subtle invariants of rings defined by Quillen in the 1970s. These record important information about the ring, but they are extremely difficult to compute. Transformative work of Goodwillie and of Boekstedt--Hsiang--Madsen connected these groups to the much more computable topological Hochschild homology groups, and this created the trace methods approach to algebraic K-theory.

The workshop brought together experts in motivic homotopy theory and in trace methods, building opportunities for cross-field discussions. The workshop and conference gave chances for mathematicians to share recent results and to discuss common approaches and techniques.

Broader Impacts:

This award supported the travel of early-career researchers to the paired events. This provided students and postdocs with two important opportunities. First, it allowed them to discuss mathematics related to their research with experts from across the globe. The talks introduced them to cutting-edge mathematics, grounding their work in a broader context. The breaks between talks provided chances to discuss mathematics in more details. Second, many early-career mathematicians were also able to give short talks about their own mathematics. This will help any who stay in academia by ensuring experts in the community had an opportunity to hear and ask questions about their ongoing research.


Last Modified: 11/14/2024
Modified by: Michael A Hill
